newsitem.title: ITALY: All unions back Italy metalworkers pay proposal.
newsitem.headline: All unions back Italy metalworkers pay proposal.

text.p: A government proposal to end a months-long pay dispute in Italy's key engineering and metalworking industry was endorsed on Tuesday by all three trades unions in the sector.

A senior official of the FIOM union, the most sceptical of the three, said the proposed deal had been endorsed by a meeting of the union's leadership. The other two unions, FIM and UILM, approved the deal separately at meetings earlier on Tuesday.
"It was approved by 66 votes...to 37 with 24 abstentions," Maurizio Zipponi, FIOM leader for the northern town of Brescia, said after the union meeting.

The employers' group Federmeccanica has yet to announce its position on the government's proposal, presented on Monday after all-night talks with the parties. Another meeting was expected to take place at the Labour Ministry on Tuesday evening.
UILM, FIM and FIOM represent 1.7 million workers in a sector which accounts for 40 percent of Italian industrial output. Their two-year contract expired in June.

The government has proposed extending the contract to 30 months. The employers would make a one-off payment of 512,000 lire ($316) paid in two instalments to cover the first six months, followed by graduated monthly wage increases totalling 200,000 lire ($124) during the rest of the contract.
